facts: Civics is the study of how people work together in a community and how government is organized.
In a democracy, citizens choose leaders by voting in elections.
The U.S. Constitution sets the rules for the national government and limits what it can do.
The Bill of Rights is the first ten amendments to the U.S. Constitution and lists important freedoms like speech and religion.
Separation of powers divides government into three branches—legislative, executive, and judicial—so no one branch becomes too powerful.
Checks and balances let each branch of government stop or limit actions by the other branches to help prevent unfair decisions.
A citizen has rights such as freedom of expression and responsibilities such as obeying laws and serving on a jury when called.
